executive_summary: The Millwork industry manufactures wood-based architectural products, including doors, windows and flooring. These reshaped wood products are key components of construction projects. As general construction activity increases, so will demand for millwork. Most millwork products are used in residential construction, split evenly between new housing construction and renovations. While competition from steel, aluminum, vinyl and other materials is intense for nonresidential construction, sales to this sector still account for a relatively small portion of industry revenue.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: HOME IMPROVEMENTS PROVIDE A BOON FOR MILLWORKERS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Millwork products are essential in the construction and maintenance of residential and nonresidential buildings. Millwork manufacturers are particularly reliant on the renovation market, as many homeowners undertake home improvement projects to increase the value of their homes. Wood-based products are considered upgrades over their alternatives, making them popular additions for home renovations.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: NEW HOUSING CONSTRUCTION SURGED EARLY ON IN THE PERIOD
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The residential construction market covers work on single- and multi-family homes and apartment buildings. Millworkers produce dimension lumber, which involves sawing and planting purchased lumber into standardized dimensions. Lumber constitutes most of the materials used in the framing of the typical single-family house, so industry revenue tends to move closely in line with housing starts.

Since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short time to complete, the level of activity within the residential building market is highly susceptible to the price of financing. Low interest rates fueled growth throughout 2020 and 2021. However, the Federal Reserve has increased interest rates to maintain sustainable economic growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Heightened Substitute Competition Siphons Away Demand
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The rising use of substitute architectural products has and continues to hurt millwork manufacturers. Window frames and doorframes made from aluminum, steel, fiberglass and vinyl have become increasingly popular. Vinyl, currently the fastest-growing segment within the window frame market, offers a low-cost alternative to wooden window frames and doorframes.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: RISING INTEREST RATES WILL MITIGATE DEMAND COMPARED WITH THE PRIOR PERIOD
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Interest rates will continue to remain high over the outlook period. Since home building and renovation projects take a relatively short amount of time to complete, the level of activity within the residential building market is highly susceptible to the price of financing.

The window and door segment will continue to face increased competition, with substitutes having the most significant impact on revenue. Wood accounts for the bulk of interior door volume, but more expensive and more profitable exterior doors will continue to be made of alternative materials.

The nonresidential construction market will strongly bounce back from the lows endured in the prior period. Healthy economic conditions will enable nonresidential contractors to properly plan out and execute large-scale projects.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Maintaining Profitability Will Be Paramount To Succeed
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Many millwork manufacturers are downsizing with the hopes of maintaining profitability. Revenue is set to grow at a faster rate than wages over the next five years, sustaining profitability.

industry_definition: This industry manufactures hardwood and softwood cut stock and dimension stock (lumber and worked wood products cut or shaped into specific sizes); wood windows and doors; and other millwork including wood flooring. The reshaped wood products are sold mainly to housing and other building construction industries and their contractors, in addition to other wood product distributors.

negative_impact_factors: low - steady Barriers To Entry Level

market_segmentation.segment_description: The largest market for millworkers is new residential construction. This segment boomed as the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates to stimulate

Home improvement projects are the industry's second-largest downstream market. Wooden doors, windows and flooring are often viewed as higher-end building products and are frequently installed as upgrades in existing dwellings. Home improvement spending is determined by homeownership rates, access to credit and consumer disposable income. Like the new residential construction market, low interest rates boosted demand, but reversing trends caused this market to slump in the latter half. Recovery is well underway, however, as interest rates have stabilized.

Millwork manufacturers faces stronger competition in nonresidential construction markets. Commercial buildings tend to be constructed more from substitute materials like steel or fiberglass. Since commercial buildings are often larger than residential dwellings, it can be cost prohibitive to use high-end wood products. Activity within this segment has historically taken longer to improve post-recession because of the long lead times associated with the larger commercial projects. Nonetheless, this market has recovered as complications have dissipated.

products_and_services.product_description: Products in this segment include wooden windows and door units, sashes, window frames and doorframes and doors made from wood or from wood clad with metal or plastics.

products_and_services.product_or_service: Cut Stock, Resawed Lumber and Planed Lumber
products_and_services.product_description: Dimension stock is lumber from either hardwood or softwood timber that has been finished and cut to a standardized width and depth. Commonly used as a cheap building material, softwood lumber makes up the majority of this segment's revenue. This segment also includes stock purchased from sawmills and cut to specific shapes or sizes, along with planed lumber that has been finished or smoothed to a predetermined thickness.

This product segment includes wood flooring, wood columns, decorative wood moldings, door shutters, railings, trellises and ornamental woodwork. These products are typically sold to tradesmen for manufacturing floors, decking, furniture and other wood products that require a structural frame. This segment has been the fastest-growing in the industry in part due to the increased popularity of hardwood flooring. The segment is also the industry's most profitable and its expansion has raised the average profit margin.

tier_1_suppliers: Sawmills & Wood Production in the US
Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Electric Power Transmission in the US
Industrial Machinery & Equipment Wholesaling in the US
Power Tools & Other General Purpose Machinery Manufacturing in the US
tier_1_buyers: Apartment & Condominium Construction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: The level of housing construction activity significantly influences demand within the Millwork industry. The sector supplies components such as wooden window frames, doors, hardwood floors and other dimension stocks that are integral to residential construction. A rise in housing starts directly benefits the industry by increasing demand for these products.

Private spending on home improvements, upgrades and repairs directly impacts millwork demand, particularly for floor, door and window construction. This expenditure correlates with per capita disposable income and home sales.

As per capita disposable income increases, consumers are more inclined to build new homes or invest in remodeling existing ones. This tendency boosts home improvement spending, driving demand for millwork products like wooden doorframes, windows, floors and trim. Disposable income trends by the unemployment rate and inflation. More employed individuals typically generate additional disposable income, encouraging higher home improvement spending.

Residential homes represent the primary market for the millwork industry, with homeowners significantly influencing demand. While landlords also construct and renovate buildings using aesthetically appealing wooden products, they may opt for cost-effective alternatives such as plastic or wood composites. These materials offer visual appeal at a lower cost, creating competition for millwork products. Homeownership rates directly impact demand for industry-specific wooden materials.

Despite strong competition from materials like steel, aluminum and vinyl in nonresidential construction, sales to this sector still contribute about one-tenth of industry revenue. The millwork industry's revenue positively correlates with commercial and industrial construction activity levels. Increased nonresidential construction activities enhance demand for millwork products, highlighting the sector's significance. Declines in the value of private nonresidential construction pose a potential threat to the industry.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Weak Peso Increases Demand from Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: A weak peso has made products manufactured in Mexico cheaper for US consumers. This exchange rate advantage incentivizes US companies to import more from Mexico, reducing their purchasing costs. This economic dynamic has significantly bolstered Mexico's role as a key trade partner for the US.

international_trade_points.trade_title: South America Continues to be the Largest Source of Industry Imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Brazil, Chile and Mexico play pivotal roles in the global millwork market, collectively accounting for a substantial share of millwork imports. Brazil is renowned for its vast forest resources, offering various wood products such as doors, moldings and panels. Chile benefits from intensive forestry practices, primarily exporting high-quality pine and eucalyptus millwork. These nations contribute significantly to meeting the international demand for millwork, combining abundant natural resources with skilled craftsmanship to supply diverse, high-quality, cost-effective wood products.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The Largest Destination for Industry Exports is Canada
international_trade_points.trade_description: Established in 2020, the USMCA facilitated smoother cross-border trade by updating provisions from NAFTA. It includes new rules on digital trade, Intellectual Property, Labor and Environmental Standards. The USMCA has created a balanced and modernized trade environment by reducing tariffs, lowering costs for businesses and consumers. It streamlined customs procedures and enhanced market access, resulting in increased trade volumes, economic integration and mutual prosperity for Canada, the United States and Mexico. Canada, in particular, is the industry's largest export destination.

international_trade_points.trade_title: A Depreciating Dollar Will Boost Export Volumes Over the Next Five Years
international_trade_points.trade_description: When the trade-weighted index falls, the US dollar weakens relative to other major currencies. This makes US goods cheaper for foreign buyers, potentially increasing demand for US exports. US industries may enjoy growth because of the enhanced competitiveness of their products globally. Stringent regulations and standards in domestic manufacturing often result in superior product quality compared to countries with laxer regulations. As international markets seek high-quality products, demand for US-made goods rises. Higher demand boosts domestic manufacturing, resulting in economic growth and increased market share abroad.

business_locations.location_description: Florida is the largest producer in the region, although industry establishments are distributed throughout the region. The Southeast is the nation's largest producer of lumber; almost half of all logging companies are located in the region. Since millwork establishments primarily purchase materials from sawmills, millwork manufacturers choose to locate near these upstream industry establishments to reduce transportation expenses and save time.

Millwork manufacturers benefit from the ready access to raw materials since the Great Lakes is the third-most popular destination for logging companies and the second-most popular destination for sawmill operators. Millworkers choose to locate in the region due to its proximity to Canada, which is the largest export market for the United States.

California has the nation's largest concentration of establishments. Millwork manufacturers choose to locate in the region due to the ready supply of raw materials. Also, California is particularly attractive because of its large consumer markets and strong housing demand. The housing boom in California significantly boosted the state's share of total establishments.

The region has the fourth-largest share of sawmill facilities in the nation, so millwork manufacturers choose to locate near these upstream establishments. This saves on transportation fees and time. The region includes densely populated cities in New York and New Jersey, which provide a strong source of demand for both residential and nonresidential construction.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Clean Water Act (CWA), The Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA) and The Clean Air Act (CAA)
regulations_points.regulation_description: Under the CWA and RCRA, millwork manufacturers are responsible for following appropriate water and solid waste discharge procedures.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE CLUSTER RULE AND NOISE CONTROL
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Cluster Rule protects human health and the environment by reducing toxic releases to the air and water. The rule applies to most manufacturers in the United States and is enforced by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). The US Code governs noise regulation. The law lists the types of industrial machinery considered and requires the EPA to monitor progress through developed noise emission standards.

OSHA sets stringent safety standards to protect workers in the millwork industry from machinery hazards, requiring proper machine guarding and safety protocols. It mandates hazard communication for hazardous substances, ensuring labels and Safety Data Sheets (SDS) are accessible. Employers must provide personal protective equipment (PPE) such as gloves and goggles. OSHA enforces noise control standards to minimize workers' exposure to harmful noise.

The CPSC enforces safety standards to protect consumers from hazardous products in the millwork industry, such as banning lead-based paints. It monitors product safety, requiring the recall of defective or dangerous items like poorly constructed windows and doors. Compliance with the Consumer Product Safety Act ensures that millwork products meet stringent safety criteria, reducing the risk of injuries and promoting consumer confidence.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The capital intensity level is low.
The industry concentration level is low.
The level of technology change is low.

basis_points.basis_description: Competitive pricing is key to attracting downstream customers in a relatively low-margin industry.
Millworkers must also be able to deliver a range of high-quality products that have aesthetic appeal.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The industry began from localized operations near heavily forested regions of the United States, limited by transportation abilities and overall demand conditions.
No single company currently accounts for a market share of more than 5.0%. Industry market share concentration is expected to remain fairly low as most participants continue to cater to local demand.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: INCREASING SELLING PRICES MUTES PROFIT DECLINES
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: - Profit as a share of revenue has decreased over the past five years. - Profit declines are largely attributable to rising labor and purchase costs. - Labor expenses have grown faster than revenue, squeezing profit. However, this decline in profitability has been somewhat mitigated by the industry's ability to increase selling prices. These price hikes are justified by the perceived higher value of millwork products compared to non-wood substitutes. - Consistent price adjustments have helped manage the profit decline, but these measures may only offer short-term relief without addressing the underlying cost issues.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: SKILLED LABOR IS HIGHLY IMPORTANT, RESULTING IN HIGH WAGE COSTS
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: - Wages as a share of revenue have increased over the past five years.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases Continue to Dominate Millwork Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases as a share of revenue has increased over the past five years. Purchases of reworked and engineered hardwood and softwood from veneer, plywood producers and sawmills have increasingly dominated millwork costs over the past five years. As a share of revenue, purchase costs have risen, reflecting their essential role in production.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The millworking industry, which supplies custom woodwork, cabinetry and other building components, is highly responsive to construction trends. A period of low Federal Reserve interest rates spurred a flurry of residential construction activity, benefiting millworkers with extensive demand growth. However, as interest rates began to rise, borrowing costs increased, cooling the housing market and, by extension, demand for millwork products.

Millwork manufacturers are sensitive to changes in household disposable income, as private spending on home improvements is a prominent downstream market. Higher household income drives purchases of more premium products.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Technological innovations are streamlining the manufacturing process
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Computer-controlled cutting equipment has enabled millwork manufacturers to make products that are more standardized. This also cuts down on manufacturing errors, which boosts product quality and reduces returns. Just-in-time inventory control systems provides customers with more consistent delivery times and reduces inventory costs. Making the purchasing process easier for customers has been a primary focus for manufacturers, as it boosts repeat purchases and fosters better relationships.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Millwork manufacturers are delving into the do-it-yourself market
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Millworkers are increasingly adopting modular product designs. These are easier for customers to install and mount and also enables millworkers to standardize the manufacturing process. Although the do-it-yourself market is relatively small, these buyers tend to be very passionate about their craft and purchase a significant quantity, making them a niche, but profitable segment of buyers.

FAQs.question: How is your company affected by rising imports?
FAQs.answer: Millwork manufacturers have contended with competition from foreign-made products, but imports continue to have a low market share. Foreign-made millwork items are less expensive to manufacture, increasing price-based competition.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Industry performance is closely tied to the health of the US housing sector, making it highly cyclical. That being said, industry performance can still outperform during times of broader macroeconomic challenges.

FAQs.question: Has your company been exposed to volatile input prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: Lumber prices have fluctuated in response to swings in construction markets domestically and abroad, making industry input prices volatile.

FAQs.question: Has your company located near key downstream distributors to reduce shipping costs?
FAQs.answer: Many industry manufacturers locate close to population centers that exhibit high levels of construction activity.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to reduce wage costs through automation in recent years?
FAQs.answer: Despite the availability of woodworking machinery, labor costs in the industry have remained relatively steady.

FAQs.question: Is your company investing in technology such as 3D printing to establish a competitive edge?
FAQs.answer: 3D printing technology can make building product manufacturers more competitive by enabling the easier production of prototypes and enhancing customization abilities.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: The industry is not heavily regulated and worker health and safety represents its greatest liability.

FAQs.question: How does your company compensate for seasonality of cash flow?
FAQs.answer: New construction and renovations tend to slow down in the winter months, making the industry's business somewhat seasonal.

FAQs.question: What percentage of your customers renew their contracts?
FAQs.answer: Maintaining relationships with downstream retailers can be very important to manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do you have contacts with key distributors and end users? How can you secure more of these supply contracts?
FAQs.answer: Established showroom networks enable manufacturers to sell their products in key consumer markets, thereby generating brand recognition.

FAQs.question: Do you have access to the latest available and most efficient technology and techniques? How frequently do you replace your equipment?
FAQs.answer: Investment in efficient plant and machinery is a key to success to ensure that product manufacturing can change to meet consumer preferences and to achieve greater efficiency.

FAQs.question: How much of your production is devoted to premium products? How can you improve your advertising campaigns?
FAQs.answer: Focusing on the high-quality end of the market will help gain future sales if coupled with promotional campaigns, which further develop brand recognition.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in the homeownership rate affected your company in the past? Do you specialize in residential products?
FAQs.answer: Residential homes are the primary market for this industry, giving homeowners control over demand for millwork.

FAQs.question: Do you expect major changes in demand as a result of rising disposable income levels? How do you plan to diversify your product mix?
FAQs.answer: Manufacturers of wood windows, doors and flooring compete with products made from substitute materials, such as vinyl, fiberglass and aluminum.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in housing starts affected your company in the past? How can you expand your reach in the residential construction market?
FAQs.answer: The level of activity within the housing construction sector largely determines demand for the Millwork industry.
